section.title: Sine and Cosine on the Unit Circle
section.p: In this section, we will further explore the connection between the unit circle and sine and cosine. We have defined traveling counterclockwise on the unit circle to be the positive direction and clockwise to be the negative direction. Assume that all arcs begin from \left(1,0 \right) unless specified otherwise.

row.cell: Coordinates at the Endpoint of Arc

section.p: lists various lengths for arcs, together with the coordinates of the arc’s endpoint.

figure.caption: Ordered Pairs (Length of Arc, x-coordinate of Endpoint)

section.p: Since we are walking around the unit circle, the units for all arc lengths are radians. In studying the entries of this table, we look at ordered pairs of the form (length of arc, x-coordinate at endpoint of arc). For instance, a length of 0 is paired with an x-coordinate of 1; a length of \pi is paired with an x-coordinate of -1; and a length of \frac{3\pi}{2} is paired with an x-coordinate of 0. These ordered pairs are graphed in , and we recognize the shape of the cosine curve. The x-coordinate of the endpoint of the arc varies from 1 to -1 as the length of the arc changes; this is why the range of the cosine function contains all real numbers from -1 to 1. Whether the arc length is s units or s+2\pi units, the arc ends at the same point. This is why the range of the cosine function repeats every 2\pi units, and the cosine function has period 2\pi.

figure.caption: Ordered Pairs (Length of Arc, y-coordinate of Endpoint)

section.p: Now let us look at ordered pairs of the form (length of arc, y-coordinate at endpoint of arc). These ordered pairs include \left(0,0 \right), \left(\frac{\pi}{2},1 \right),\left(-\frac{\pi}{2},-1 \right), and so forth, and are graphed in . We will come to recognize this as the shape of the sine curve.

subsection.title: A Pythagorean Identity
subsection.p: The sine and cosine functions are often called circular functions because their definitions are based on a unit circle. Since the coordinates of all points on the unit circle satisfy the equation x^2+y^2=1, it follows that \left(\cos \left(s \right) \right)^2 + \left(\sin \left(s \right) \right)^2=1. We usually write \left(\cos \left(s \right) \right)^2 as \cos^2 s, so this equation can be written as \cos^2 \left(s \right) + \sin^2 \left(s \right)=1. This equation is an identity since it is true for all values of the variable s. Even further, it is known as one of the “Pythagorean Identities” due to its relationship to a right triangle embedded in the unit circle (as discussed earlier in this chapter). The fact that \cos^2 \left(s \right)+\sin^2 \left(s \right)=1 is an identity means that in any equation or expression, \cos^2 x+\sin^2 x can be replaced by 1 regardless of value we choose for x. For example, \cos^2 \left(0.436 \right)+ \sin^2 \left(0.436 \right)= 1 and \cos^2 \left(-5.278 \right)+ \sin^2 \left(-5.278 \right)=1.

We can also replace \cos^2 x + \sin^2 x with 1 in any equation. For example, if we want to solve \sin^2 x + \sin x \cos x + \cos^2 x=0, we could simplify this to \sin x \cos x=-1. Of course, it doesn’t matter what variable is used, so \cos^2 t can be replaced by 1-\sin^2 t, and \sin^2 \theta can be replaced by 1-\cos^2 \theta whenever it is advantageous to do so.

statement.p: An ant starts at \left(1,0 \right) and walks in a counterclockwise direction 4 units along the circumference of a unit circle. In what quadrant does the ant stop? What are the coordinates of the point where the ant stops?

solution.p: To determine the quadrant in which the ant stops, we need to compare the distance it walks (4 units) to other arc lengths. The ant walked more than half-way around the circle, since 4 \gt \pi, but it did not walk around the entire circle since 4 \lt 2\pi. It would have walked three-quarters of the way around the circle if the length of its trip had been \frac{3\pi}{2}. Since 4 \lt \frac{3\pi}{2}, the ant walked less than three-quarters of the way around the circle. Therefore, it ended its trip in the third quadrant.

The coordinates of the point where the ant stops are exactly \left(\cos 4, \sin 4 \right). We can approximate \cos 4 and \sin 4 using a calculator. We find that the ant stops at the point whose coordinates are approximately \left(-0.6536,-0.7568 \right). (Verify that \left(-0.6536 \right)^2 + \left(-0.7568 \right)^2 is approximately 1.)
